text: After President Donald Trump declared that terrorist leader Abubakar al-Baghdadi had died, Trump repeated his inaccurate pride in calling for the elimination of Osama bin Laden before the attacks of 11 September. "You know, if you read my book -- there was a book right before the World Trade Center went down. And I don't get any credit for this, but that's okay. I never do that. But here we are. I've written a book that's really very successful. In that book, about a year before the World Trade Center bombing, I said, "There's a guy named Osama bin Laden. You'd better kill him or kill him. The Trump reference to bin Laden relates to the bombing by the United States of its camps in Afghanistan and the Sudan on August 20, 1998. Clinton said that they were in retaliation for terrorist bombings earlier that month on the United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing 224 people, including 12 Americans, and injuring thousands. Clinton said that the target of the American strikes was "the corruption of Bin Laden's terrorist network." Trump devoted a chapter to terrorism and warned widely that America could be attacked, but did not call for the elimination of bin Laden. He wrote that the United States "should prepare for the real possibility that somewhere, at some point, he will carry a weapon of mass destruction to a major American city and blow up." Trump admitted that this was not his original idea, noting that "Nightline" ABC-TV had broadcast a series of presentations about the threat. But no one has ever heard of Osama bin Laden until, indeed, the World Trade Center." The U.S. government was aware of bin Laden a few years before the September 11 attacks. The CIA set up a unit in 1996, Alec Station, to hunt down bin Laden when he was advocating global jihad. The station was dissolved a decade later. In his 2000 book, the Governor Trump said, "I was talking about Osama bin Laden. And I said to him, "You have to kill him. "Trump has inaccurately described what he wrote in his own book. The core of the only truth here is that Trump wrote about bin Laden in the context of criticism of President Clinton.
